msContents.summary: Record of a legal dispute brought by the daughter of a deceased Roman soldier, Amatius Priscus, against her aunt. According to this document, the will was made in the twelfth year of the deified emperor Hadrian (117-138) and stated that the deceased's estate was to be divided equally between the two women. Rufus, the representative of one of the women, asks the council hearing the matter to appoint an arbiter.

msItemStruct.note: Bar code: 47820295. Other texts recording legal proceedings in language much like this one are Berlin Gr. Urk. 136 and 388, both probably of the second century, and Oxyrhynchus Papyri 37 and 40. For another reference to Amatia Prisca, also called Lucia, see Kenyon, Greek Papyri II, 212.

condition.ab: The papyrus is a short roll. Twenty letters are missing from the beginning of the first column. The condition of the innermost edge makes it probable that the third column of the fragment was the last one of the complete roll, a suggestion corroborated by the contents of that column, where a decision is evidently being reached. (Goodspeed 1904, 29)

layout.ab: Source of description: On recto: Legal dispute

handDesc.p: Written in a bold, clear, semi-uncial hand, in broad, well-spaced columns. Parts of three of the columns are preserved.
